section.title: Location-Speakers
section.para: Varieties and subdialects of the Western Omo-Tana language Arbore are spoken near Lake Stefanie.

biblioentry.title: The Arbore Language: A First Investigation Including a Vocabulary

section.title: arbore Paradigm Lexemes
section.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms
Lemma Gloss Properties
beeḳoW- become wounded dervStem=inchoative, pos=verb
hariyAƊ- feel (tr.) dervStem=middle1, pos=verb
kumAHAƊ- bow dervStem=middle3, pos=verb
raf- sleep conjClass=suffix, dervStem=base, pos=verb, subConj=nonContracting
rakkAƊƊ- experience trouble dervStem=middle4, pos=verb
waññoHAƊ- become old dervStem=middle2, pos=verb
zer(e)n- pierce conjClass=suffix, pos=verb, subConj=contracting
ñoorIS- cause to arrive dervStem=causative1, pos=verb
ʔEEčč- come conjClass=prefix, patternClass=pattern2, pos=verb
ʔElɗ- ~ ʔEll- ~ ḳeʔ-(suff) stand patternClass=pattern2, pos=verb
ʔEḳEs- ~ ʔigis- kill conjClass=prefix, pattenClass=pattern2, pos=verb
ʔIk(k)In- swallow conjClass=prefix, patternClass=pattern1, pos=verb
ʔInḅIt- step conjClass=prefix, patternClass=pattern1, pos=verb

section.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
section.para: Arbore paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para: Arbore follows the Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern.
clauseType: There are important formal distinctions between main-clause and relative clause verb forms.

inflectionClass: as in all languages, phonological and grammaticization processes conspire to create more or less marked morphophonemic differences in the verbal inflections of different sets of verbs.
stemAltClass: category-governed stem alternations (Hayward1984 secc. 5.1.2 and 5.3.2.1; an open set of classes
contracting: suffix lexical verbs with CVCVC~CVCC alternation
nonContracting: suffix-class lexical verbs without syllabicity alternation

section.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
section.para:
The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first simply lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The second listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,⊤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].

table.caption: Table 1: Prop:Val List of Default Paradigms
